result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

1:24 PM Defendant Ezekiel L. Smith in court.  Prosecuting attorney Kelly A Cassidy in court for the State of Wisconsin.

BY THE COURT:
Warrants are quashed.

Court will make a dean appointment and Court will proceed by appointing a court appointed attorney.

1:57 PM Prosecuting attorney Jedidiah J Dodge in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Ezekiel L. Smith appeared by video, in custody.  

Court questions Atty Bender regarding representing him today. 
Atty Bender indicates he is representing him on a case that is set for status on an older case.  The defendant needs to apply to have him appointed on this new file. 
Atty Soule and Atty Bergner are in court and will contact their office to have someone see him at the jail to get started on that. 
Atty Bender notes if he is eligible he will take on this case. 
Court questions Atty Bender. 
Court questions the defendant regarding in custody status. 
Defendant responds. He is sitting a sanction and should be released on 7/25.

BY THE COURT:  Bond continued.

12:54 PM Defendant Ezekiel L. Smith appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Kelly A Cassidy in court for State of Wisconsin. 

This is before the Court for a bond review.
Defendant is requesting a bond modification.
Court had contacted both the District Attorney's Office and the Public Defender's Office.
Per the Public Defender's Office the Defendant is requesting to represent himself.
Defendant puts his bond modification request on the record.
ADA Cassidy is objecting to the request of the bond modification and states her reasons on the record.
ADA Cassidy indicates that the defendant is eligible for State Public Defender representation but the defendant indicates he wishes to retain his own counsel.
ADA Cassidy indicates that they have attempted to contact the victim but was unsuccessful.
Defendant makes statements that he wishes to have Atty Bender represent him on this case as he already represents him on his other case.
Court questions the defendant where he will reside; he responds.
Defendant makes additional statements.
Court questions the defendant as to what he is on probation for.  
Defendant states he is on extended supervision until approx. 2024 or 2025.
Court makes statements to the defendant prior to making his decision on the bond modification.

BY THE COURT:
If the defendant can show he is on GPS then the Court will modify the bond to a $2,500 signature bond.
Defendant needs to provide the jail with his current address prior to release.
Needs to appear back in Court on June 20, 2022 @ 1:15 p.m.
Defendant is to contact the public defender's office and let them know that they need to appoint Atty Richard Bender on his new case.
Defendant is not have absolutely no contact with E.W.

1:19 PM Defendant Ezekiel L Smith appeared by video from the Portage County Jail.  Attorney Andrew Mutchler in court for State of WI. 
Atty Mutchler calls the case and states the appearances. 

ADA Mutchler states facts for anticipated charges of felony bail jumping and misdemeanor battery. 
Court finds probable cause that a crime has been committed and that this defendant committed it.

Court informs defendant of right to an attorney and/or public defender.

State requests a $1,500 cash bond with conditions as stated. 

Court questions defendant regarding being on probation.
Mr. Smith responds.
Mr. Smith makes further statements to the court.
Court questions if Mr. Smith has any cash to post for bond.
Mr. Smith responds further.
